author: timbeiko
content: Given this server is for technical/R&D discussions, I don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs the best approach. I think it‚Äôs fine to talk about censorship resistance in the context of many aspects of the protocol, such as the merge, <#874767108809031740>, etc. But given it‚Äôs already a topic wheee emotions run high and it can be hard to ‚Äúground‚Äù the conversation, I‚Äôd rather not have a channel _just_ for that. There are obviously many other places where discussion about this is happening - this discord doesn‚Äôt have to cover *everything* üòÖ

author: greysonmage
content: Re DAG size, is it reaching exactly 5gb that (maybe) matters, or exceeding 5gb? Think the former has happened but the latter not yet

author: lukaszrozmej
content: no, but its not that a big deal to get ready, some wiring and integrating

author: tmiychao
content: Monitoring hashrate after DAG reached 5GB (green vertical line). It slightly decreased, before it was around 900TH/s, since then the average is 869TH/s. Not significant but timeframe is small, it could still be a noise

author: greysonmage
content: Sounds good and makes sense, have heard people say that 5gb is an uncommon size for mining hardware. But just want to confirm we are watching for hashrate change at the right threshold. Reaching, rather than exceeding, 5gb is what would affect hardware that has 5gb memory?

author: schneeball.eth
content: Hi. What happens if a validator cant update their CL client to a Bellatrix ready version in time? e.g. i am on vacation from now til the 9. of september.

author: djrtwo
content: validator will be offline and will stand to lose approximately what they would have stood to make

author: djrtwo
content: so it's totally fine for 3 days

author: djrtwo
content: will lose a little for 3 days, then you can upgrade, and gain that loss back in 3 days

author: schneeball.eth
content: Ok. Thats fine with me. Thanks üôÇ

author: mkkoll
content:
<@301186049323958275> ‚ù§Ô∏è ‚ù§Ô∏è ‚ù§Ô∏è 
"The social consensus of the protocol is a credible threat to bad actors"

author: chris2_2_2
content:
Interesting enough I didn‚Äôt expect it but many a10 ASICS stopped being able to mine eth at 5 even if they are 6-7gb. Innosilicon told them to just mine etc for now. So there should be a significant drop off.

(Might want to wait another week before setting ttd since inno may release a patch so that it‚Äôs a10‚Äôs rejoin).

author: mkkoll
content:
Engineers looking for an engineering solution to deter protocol censorship. Whodathunkit
Maybe we should rely on the social consensus part of Ethereum more?
Yes, a socially-driven slashing of a bad actor would of course be a last resort. The nuclear option. But as <@301186049323958275> says, the fact that it is even a potential threat to a bad actor, is hopefully enough to deter the attempt.

author: mkkoll
content: "Censorship at the block proposal level will not be tolerated by network participants."

author: mkkoll
content: If nation-states want to make it illegal to process and include certain transactions, then its up to the individual stakers to decide whether the threat in their legal jurisdiction is too much for them, and they can then exit the system.

author: mkkoll
content:
Core devs dont want to say explicitly whether they are for or against the censorship. I understand that.
But as a user, im here for censorship resistance and credible neutrality. If the protocol stops providing that. Im out.

author: mkkoll
content: It's somewhat poetic that we are now being forced to re-examine our beliefs in censorship resistance and credible neutrality of the protocol just weeks before the most important upgrade in Ethereums history

author: 0xsadcat
content: engineering solutions can increase the friction to censor. theoretically, if transactions/blocks were time encrypted in some way, then censorship would require a completely separate transaction submission system

author: dirigible6945
content: How much would you expect to fall off? We can always override, but a short time gap wouldn't be bad. Is it already present?

author: chris2_2_2
content: Right now looks like 50-100ths falloff but it‚Äôs too early to say. Give it a day or two so graphs become more clear.

author: vinnie9190
content:
There is a bug noted in all the Innosilicon A10 pro, which were supposedly mounting 6-7-8GB, but after 5GB DAG reached, some bug appeared in their firmware making them not being able to mine ETH. No short term solution there. They are goin to move to ETC... 

Looking at ETC nethash increase will give you a clear and fast way to address this event. There is an increase of 12 TH/s on ETC. BTW looks like, despite the similar algorithms, these machines are performing 50-70% of their rated ETH hashrate, so the real drop in the ETH mainnet should be somewhere between 15-30 TH/s.

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: The announcement will be on monday/tuesday once the client releases are out

author: postcapone
content:
It honestly isn't though

The Lido/CB/Kraken delegators will still have their eth on another fork

Real Ethereum will be forced to prove it has more value without USDC than with it.

The probability that we wind up with two very broken Ethereum's is excruciatingly high. Ethereum has to solve this before the slashening.

Threatening the slash is a powerful way to bring the social layer up to speed, and following through with the slash is an absolute must if it comes to that.

But the battle only begins there. Either you have to UASF because you cannot otherwise reach finality with an uncensored chain, or they will UASF to protect their funds and be compliant.

WalmartChain vs. PunkChain only begins here.

author: postcapone
content:
Proof of Stake introduces a very real issue:

The social layer's fork choice will follow their account balances.

Their philosophies and personal values will be rendered meaningless if their funds are missing on the censorship resistant fork.

author: .paulharris
content: This doesn't look like `merge-public` content, can we try to keep this on topic? Suggest maybe uncategorised for continuing?

author: postcapone
content: Surely no problem

author: kudeta
content: We should of course engineer away as much censorship out as possible. But private capital is usually more effective at organising itself, certainly more effective than decentralised protocol governance, which we see is a chaotic and painful process. It will also always be impossible to find consensus amongst us and even now, i'm troubled by the idea some devs don't even feeling comfortable sharing their views openly. How does anyone agree anything in that kind of situation, and how does the wider community get involved if we don't know what a large part of the most active players think? It would be good for us to have these conversations now, agree at least some red lines in advance, and coded, tested set of in protocol responses to specific scenarios, including a UASF.

author: kudeta
content: Apologies, just saw this.
